
An impatient hacker reused a nonce when signing two messages with ECDSA. Recover their private key and decrypt: Sig1: c050c3f0b8d45b9e093a91cb96d097b24100e66585d0d8561e01c1231837493f955d8c1f3ebabfaba9d2e2e6aba67540f16840cba08efae39094d2ec86088c1f
Sig2: c050c3f0b8d45b9e093a91cb96d097b24100e66585d0d8561e01c1231837493f7f556f92ab6d7b3a3d3b91163f1eac50f9681520a8bbd56a66d89774a5a58a07


Public Key (x,y): (80305967905329335431570557583110042688573549381067946887298216993662326688938, 34408117742975125325076416029425015847489624543103838435335486075561858755439)
Messages:
1. CTF challenge message
2. Second signed message
Curve: secp256k1The flag format is flag{hex(private_key)}

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{77c03f830e8ad38805c828aa0fd7095f5572496e4d03961d1761a886e306d4ee}

cipher: ECDSA Nonce Reuse
hint: Identical nonce usage breaks ECDSA security. What's common between the signatures?
